item.title: Switch 2 is getting a new 3D Donkey Kong platformer
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/switch-2-is-getting-a-new-3d-donkey-kong-platformer

The Switch 2 is getting a brand new 3D Donkey Kong platformer.

Donkey Kong Bananza won't be a launch title, but will be released on 17th July. That's a month after the console launches on 5th June.

Most notably, the game features a re-designed Donkey Kong model that appears to be the same as that used in the new Mario Kart World (and similar to his design in the Mario film).

In the trailer, we see the gorilla punching, climbing and rolling his way through 3D destructible environments.

He also has some sort of purple rock-crystal companion on his shoulder. In fact, many of the enemies appear to be made of crystals.

And of course there are both mine cart sections and 2D sections, as you'd expect from a traditional Donkey Kong game.

This will be the first 3D Donkey Kong platformer since Donkey Kong 64, and follows Donkey Kong Country Returns - the Wii remake released on Switch earlier this year. It also ties in nicely with the new Donkey Kong area of the Super Mario World theme parks.

Also at the Direct, Nintendo announced the release date and price of the Switch 2.

item.title: Final Fantasy 7 Remake is coming to Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/final-fantasy-7-remake-is-coming-to-switch-2

Final Fantasy 7 Remake Intergrade is coming to the Nintendo Switch 2, though no release date was given.

Though rumoured, the news was confirmed at today's Switch 2 Direct, along with tonnes of other games.

This is the first part only of the Remake trilogy, though will include the Intermission DLC starring Yuffie as with the Intergrade re-release on PC and PS5.

There was no mention of the second part, last year's Rebirth. "Please look forward to more updates on the Final Fantasy 7 remake project for Switch 2," said director Naoki Hamaguchi in the presentation.

Though the third part is yet to be officially revealed, it's unclear if that will be a PlayStation console exclusive at launch.

Final Fantasy 7 Remake arrives on Switch 2 five years after its initial release on PS4. While the original PS1 game is already available on the original Switch, this will be the first time Remake will be on a Nintendo console.

This is all part of Square Enix's multiplatform strategy after Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth's initial PlayStation release underperformed. The power of the Switch 2 should allow for other more recent games to be released on Nintendo's new console.

item.title: FromSoftware's The Duskbloods is Bloodborne meets Sekiro meets Dark Souls, with jetpacks and dinos thrown in
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/fromsoftwares-the-duskbloods-is-bloodborne-meets-sekiro-meets-dark-souls-with-jetpacks-and-dinos-thrown-in

And it's coming to Switch 2 next year.

Well, where to start! As part of Nintendo's Switch 2 Direct, FromSoftware has unveiled a brand-new title. It's called The Duskbloods, it's coming to Switch 2 next year, and it looks wild.

There's little information to share about The Duskbloods right now, beyond it's frankly eye-popping announcement trailer, but it looks very much like it's in the classic Soulsborne mode - just with a whole lot of everything thrown in.

It's got a huge clock tower reminiscent of Bloodborne, Eastern influences triggering recollections of Sekiro, it's got character design that looks like it's tumbled straight out of Dark Souls - and that's before we even get to the jetpacks, the steampunk influences, and the fact players can transform into blimmin' T. rexes!

Check out the trailer above and admire its zaniness for yourself. Hopefully we'll get more details about The Duskbloods soon.
